content.title: DECARBONIZING THE INDUSTRY SECTOR
content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1

content.text: The industrial sector is a major contributor to global CO2 emissions, responsible for about a quarter of energy-related emissions. Most of this comes from fossil fuel use, particularly coal. Industrial emissions have risen by 70% since 2000, driven by growing global demand for goods. While emissions stabilized during the COVID-19 pandemic, they rebounded in 2021. A 2% decline in 2022 was due mainly to reduced activity in China's industrial sector and the global energy crisis. However, emissions in other regions continued to rise, and global industrial emissions are likely to grow under a baseline scenario.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: carbon capture and storage
concepts.body: Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a technology that captures carbon dioxide emissions from sources like power plants and industrial processes, and stores it underground to prevent it from entering the atmosphere.

concepts.title: energy end-use sectors
concepts.body: Energy end-use sectors refer to the various categories of activities or industries that consume energy, such as residential, commercial, industrial, and transportation sectors.

concepts.title: energy productivity
concepts.body: Energy productivity refers to the amount of economic output generated per unit of energy consumed, indicating how efficiently energy is used in producing goods and services.

content.text: The sector consumed 37% of global energy in 2022, up from 34% in 2002. Energy demand has grown in energy-intensive subsectors. At the same time, industrial energy productivity has improved. Factors include efficient technologies, advanced equipment, and a shift toward high-value light industries like electronics.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Technological and Policy Challenges

content.text: Decarbonizing heavy industry remains complex. Many industrial processes involve chemical reactions that inherently produce CO2 emissions, such as calcination in cement production, making full decarbonization particularly challenging. Additionally, many processes require high-temperature heat, and current low-carbon technologies either cannot fully replace fossil fuels or remain prohibitively expensive. Over half of the emissions reductions needed in the IEA’s Net Zero Emissions (NZE) Scenario rely on technologies not yet market-ready. Industrial assets also have long lifetimes, making them infrequently replaced. In 2022, the industrial sector emitted 9.0 Gt of CO2. This represented a slight decline from previous years but was insufficient to meet the NZE trajectory. To reach NZE, emissions must fall to about 7 Gt CO2 by 2030, a 3% annual reduction. However, progress is hindered by the high cost of clean technologies such as green hydrogen, the absence of strong market incentives, and regulatory uncertainty. A lack of consistent carbon pricing mechanisms and industrial emissions standards further slows investment in low-carbon alternatives.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part2: Strategies for Decarbonizing the Sector

content.text: Improving energy efficiency is a cost-effective way to cut emissions. echnologies like waste heat recovery, heat pumps, and cogeneration can reduce energy use. However, efficiency improvements alone cannot achieve deep decarbonization. They can only lower fuel consumption by 15–20% in most cases. Material efficiency also offers opportunities. Recycled (secondary) production, life cycle emissions considerations, waste reduction, and circular economy models can all contribute. Governments can accelerate these shifts through regulations such as minimum efficiency performance standards for electric motors. Additionally, energy storage solutions, such as thermal storage and battery systems, can help manage energy demand fluctuations and integrate renewable power into industrial processes.

Decarbonizing hard-to-abate sectors like steel and chemicals requires multiple low-carbon technologies. Green hydrogen, produced using renewable energy, is a promising alternative to coal, with the potential to decarbonize hard-to-abate industries (sectors that rely on high-temperature heat or produce process emissions that are difficult to eliminate) such as steel, cement, and chemicals. These industries cannot easily electrify due to the nature of their production processes, making hydrogen a key alternative. Unlike fossil fuels, hydrogen combustion does not release CO2, and it can serve as both a fuel and a feedstock in industrial processes. Hydrogen demand is expected to rise from 55 Mt in 2022 to 70 Mt by 2030. Meanwhile, the electrification of industrial processes must increase. Electricity's share of the sector's energy use grows from 23% to nearly 30% by 2030, with renewable sources playing a key role under the IEA NZE Scenario.

Additionally, Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) can mitigate process emissions in sectors where direct electrification is unfeasible, though its adoption remains debated. Emerging solutions like thermal energy storage, heat pumps, and industrial battery systems also enhance energy efficiency. Combining these technologies with previously discussed energy efficiency measures can bring industry emissions close to zero.

Industrial decarbonization requires a mix of incentives and regulations to reduce emissions. Governments can support this transition by investing in research and development, helping local industries adopt affordable low-carbon technologies. Financial incentives, such as concessional loans and subsidies, can ease the high upfront costs of clean energy solutions. Voluntary agreements with businesses can encourage gradual adoption of green practices without stifling industrial growth. Public policies like green procurement can create demand for sustainable products, boosting domestic low-carbon industries. However, regulatory measures must also play a role. Emissions trading systems and carbon pricing can be adapted to local contexts, ensuring they do not disproportionately burden small and medium enterprises. Equally importantly, robust data collection, reporting, and standards are essential to track progress and attract international climate finance.

International cooperation is important for industrial decarbonization. The G7's 2022 climate club initiative and the Breakthrough Agenda started at COP26 are good examples. Similarly, global agreements such as the UAE Consensus (COP28) and the Glasgow Climate Pact (COP26) emphasize the need for technology transfer, finance, and capacity-building to support developing countries in their decarbonization efforts. Support for research, development, and deployment (RD&D) is also needed. Governments and investors should back large projects that test near zero-emission technologies. Acting early in this decade can lower costs and help these technologies spread faster. Strengthening South-South and North-South cooperation, including joint ventures, knowledge sharing, and financing mechanisms, will be key to ensuring an equitable transition for all economies.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

objectives.title: High-Temperature Industrial Processes Require Advanced Solutions.
objectives.description: Many industrial processes depend on high-temperature heat and chemical reactions that current low-carbon technologies cannot adequately replace. More than half of the required emissions reductions to achieve net-zero goals hinge on technologies that are still in development, indicating a critical gap in the industrial decarbonization landscape.

objectives.title: Efficiency Improvements Alone Are Insufficient for Deep Decarbonization.
objectives.description: While enhancing energy and material efficiency through methods like waste heat recovery, cogeneration, and circular economy practices can reduce emissions, they are not enough for achieving deeper decarbonization. Advanced technologies such as green hydrogen, industrial electrification, and Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) are essential but face significant obstacles, including high costs, inadequate infrastructure, and slow deployment rates.

objectives.title: Long Asset Lifetimes Challenge Rapid Transition to Low-Carbon Technologies.
objectives.description: The long operational lifetimes of industrial assets complicate the transition to low-carbon alternatives. The inertia created by existing investments in carbon-intensive infrastructure slows the adoption of innovative solutions. Addressing this challenge requires targeted strategies that align investment cycles with emerging low-carbon technologies while fostering supportive policies to facilitate a more rapid transition in the industrial sector.
